howILead.quote: Great design leadership isn't about having all the answers, it's about asking the right questions, creating the right environment, and empowering teams to discover solutions together.

about.title: About me
about.paragraph1: With 15+ years in design and 7+ in leadership, I've scaled design impact across 32 countries, building distributed teams that deliver measurable business outcomes. I specialize in creating inclusive, high-performing design organizations that bridge user needs with business objectives.
about.paragraph2: My approach combines strategic thinking with hands-on leadership, developing frameworks and processes that enable teams to work effectively across cultures and time zones. This includes career frameworks, quality assurance processes, and experimentation methodologies that scale globally.

hero.title: 3TPM - Global Product Architecture
hero.subtitle: Leading cross-functional design strategy to solve product variant complexity across +30 countries, enabling major partnerships and delivering measurable business impact in one quarter.

problem.title: The problem
paragraphs: Picture this: a customer in Argentina searching for "Cerveza Patricia 960ml" sees two products with identical images and names, but different pack sizes. They add the wrong one to cart, complete the purchase, and only realize the mistake when the delivery arrives.
This wasn't an isolated incident. It was a symptom of a much larger problem.
problem.quote: BEES catalog exploded from 600 to 64,000+ SKUs in just 3 years. Each of 32 markets managed taxonomy independently, same product, different images, inconsistent data, zero standardization.
additionalParagraphs: The chaos wasn't just frustrating users. It was blocking contracts with Nestlé, L'Oréal, and Gloria. These partners needed a governed, scalable platform; and our current architecture couldn't deliver it.
Search was broken, recommendations were unreliable and every new marketplace integration made things worse.

strategicChallenge.title: The strategic challenge
strategicChallenge.intro: When I took over the main shopping journey at BEES, I inherited more than broken taxonomy. I inherited a structural problem that required alignment across:
bulletPoints: Platform teams building new backend architecture (Catalog Admin, 3TPM structure)
External partners like Nestlé and L'Oréal demanding specific capabilities to go live
32 markets with different needs, languages, and business models
Multiple value streams (pricing, data, inventory) all impacted by the change
strategicChallenge.conclusion: The biggest challenge wasn't design, it was alignment. Different teams had conflicting priorities. Platform couldn't prioritize fast enough and commercial pressure was mounting.

section1.subtitle: 1. Research before solutions
paragraphs: Before defining any solution, I led qualitative field research in Argentina and São Paulo with 15+ POCs across Off Trade, On Trade, and Pharma segments. The goal: understand the real pain, not assume it.
findings: Users relied heavily on visual information, making variant differences critical
Purchase errors weren't just annoying; they eroded trust in the catalog
POCs needed clarity fast, most orders happened in high-pressure, time-constrained moments

section2.subtitle: 2. Facilitating cross-functional alignment
paragraphs: I facilitated an inception with Product, Engineering, Data Science, and Nestlé representatives. This wasn't a design review, it was a strategic alignment session.
We emerged with two clear hypotheses:

hypotheses.title: App (BEES Customer)
hypotheses.description: At the point of sale, clarity drives conversion. If the app doesn't guide the choice well, the order doesn't happen.

hypotheses.title: Platform (BEES One)
hypotheses.description: How do you scale a global B2B operation if your catalog still treats every SKU as an isolated unit?

section2.conclusion: This alignment was critical. It ensured design work wasn't just guessing, it was grounded in real user needs and tailored to our platform's strategic constraints.

section3.subtitle: 3. Validating with users
section3.description: I led 12 usability tests in São Paulo (Off Trade, On Trade, Pharma) using high-fidelity Figma prototypes. We tested two extremes: detailed variant presentation vs. simplified.
results: 60% found it easier to compare options

userQuote.quote: I click less and understand better what I'm buying.
userQuote.author: User during testing

section4.subtitle: 4. The "MVP of the MVP" decision
paragraphs: Here's where leadership mattered most. Platform teams couldn't deliver the full 3TPM architecture in time. Commercial pressure was intense. Nestlé and L'Oréal contracts were on hold.
I made the call: ship a simplified version directly in the app, without waiting for complete platform support.
meant: Building the variant selector experience in the front-end first
Accepting technical debt we'd need to refactor later
section4.conclusion: It wasn't the perfect solution. But it was the right solution for that moment.

impact.title: The impact
impact.intro: Despite shipping an "MVP of the MVP" without full platform support, results were immediate and significant:
bulletPoints: Nestlé and L'Oréal contracts unblocked within 4 weeks
Product hierarchy now scalable across 32 countries
3TPM architecture validated in real-world conditions before full backend rollout

impactCards.title: +24% Conversion
impactCards.description: Across 7 pilot markets vs. markets without the feature

impactCards.title: Contract unblocked
impactCards.description: Nestlé & L'Oréal went live 4 weeks after MVP

impactCards.title: +21% Ticket Size
impactCards.description: In Brazil, where variant clarity drove larger orders

impactCards.title: R$250k+ Orders
impactCards.description: Argentina saw order sizes over R$250,000 with improved variant selection

impact.conclusion: Critically, we achieved this in one quarter, working within severe technical and timeline constraints. The variant selector wasn't just a UX improvement. It was a business unlock.

learned.title: What I learned
intro: This project taught me that great systems aren't born from perfect screens, they're built on clear conversations, smart trade-offs, and team trust.
The biggest challenge wasn't technical. It was human:
challenges: Aligning siloed teams with conflicting priorities
Navigating political tensions between platform and product
Making tough calls when perfect wasn't possible
Holding space for the user's voice when business pressure was intense
learned.growth: I grew my influence significantly. I earned trust from engineers, PMs, data teams, and senior leadership by showing I could:
achievements: Deliver real business impact, not just polished designs
Protect the user experience when it mattered most

personalQuote.quote: This is the kind of work I love most: living at the intersection of strategic design, business impact, and cross-functional leadership.
personalQuote.author: Myself
